metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. D. N. Ganguli and Others

facts.text: Workmen of Bata Shoe Co. Ltd., Digha, Patna formed a union post-World War II with president Mr. John and general secretary Mr. Fateh Narain Singh.
On June 22, 1947, company entered into collective agreement with union; Standing Orders certified under Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946; union recognised as sole bargaining agency.
Towards end of 1954, two rival groups in union: one led by Fateh Narain Singh, other by Mr. Bari.
On January 22, 1954, union secretary Fateh Narain Singh served slow down notice effective February 24, 1954.
On February 6, 1954, Mr. Bari, purporting as president, asked followers to strike from February 23, 1954.
Demands by Fateh led to conciliation; settlement recorded on February 8, 1954.
Despite settlement, some workmen including 60 in question (Bari supporters) went on illegal strike on February 23, 1954; bound by settlement as union members.
Majority opposed strike; letter from 500 workmen on February 16, 1954 dissociating from strike.
Strike partial: out of 854 workmen, nearly 500 attended despite threats.
Strike declared illegal by government under s.23(c) ID Act.
Company served charge-sheets; dismissed 274 including 60 workmen.
Union negotiated with company: 110 strikers to be employed (76 already employed); 30 remain dismissed ineligible; 30 cases for later reemployment.
60 workmen did not demand reinstatement individually or collectively; no other body raised their case.
Union dispute with company over dismissed strikers settled by agreement.
On September 3, 1954, Conciliation Officer Mr. Sinha wrote to company for conciliation on some dismissed workmen.
Dispute of 60 not sponsored by any organisation; union secretary objected to reference on September 22, 1954.
October 8, 1954: Bihar Govt Notification No. III DI-1602/54-L-15225 referred dispute re 31 workmen dismissal to tribunal (Mr. Ali Hassan), Ref No. 10/1954.
January 15, 1955: Notification No. III DI-1601/55 L. 696 referred dispute re 29 other workmen to same tribunal, Ref No. 1/1955.
Tribunal consolidated two references; proceedings pending and progressed.
May 30, 1955: Union applied to tribunal alleging majority opposed reinstatement of 60, no interest in proceedings.
Other workmen applied to join proceedings opposing reinstatement; rejected by tribunal.
Mr. Fateh Narain Singh moved Labour Dept, Bihar Govt.
September 17, 1955: Notification No. III DI-1601/55-L-13028 superseding prior two, combining 60 workmen, adding Bata Mazdoor Union, referring to same tribunal.
September 19, 1955: Tribunal cancelled hearings fixed for October 3, 1955 for prior references, closed files.
Bata Company filed M.J.C. No. 546/1955; workmen filed M.J.C. No. 590/1955 in Patna HC under Arts. 226/227 praying quash third notification.

April 4, 1956: Patna HC held govt had no power to supersede, allowed applications, issued certiorari quashing Sep 17 notification, mandamus to tribunal to proceed with Refs 10/1954 and 1/1955 expeditiously.
June 26, 1956: State obtained leave from SC for appeals.

legal_issues.text: Where an industrial dispute has been referred to a tribunal for adjudication by the appropriate government under s.10(1)(d) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, can the said government supersede the said reference pending adjudication before the tribunal constituted for that purpose?

petitioner_arguments.text: Govt has implied power to cancel/supersede reference under s.10(1) via s.21 General Clauses Act; acted bona fide in interests of fair-play, justice, industrial peace by adding union and consolidating disputes.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(1) ID Act; s.21 General Clauses Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Necessary to hear union; more convenient comprehensive form.

respondent_arguments.text: Government has no power or authority to supersede earlier notifications referring disputes to tribunal.

court_reasoning.text: Bona fides irrelevant if no authority to cancel; Act does not expressly confer power to cancel/supersede reference under s.10(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: If no authority, bona fides cannot validate.

court_reasoning.text: s.21 General Clauses Act is rule of construction; depends on scheme, context, effect of ID Act; policy to secure industrial peace via conciliation then adjudication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Once referred, tribunal seized; govt stands outside except s.10(5).

court_reasoning.text: s.20(3): proceedings commence on reference, conclude on enforceable award; s.17 award final; inconsistent with cancellation power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme leaves reference to tribunal jurisdiction.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso s.10, s.10(2), s.12(5) inconsistent with cancellation without reasons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Govt obligated in some cases; cancellation would undermine.

court_reasoning.text: If parties settle pending reference, tribunal can award in terms of settlement; no need to cancel.
s.10(3), s.33 impose status quo during pendency; cancellation would affect obligations.
No principle supports absolute implied power to cancel without conditions or new reference.
Distinguished Minerva Mills (no cancellation, new tribunal after expiry); Strawboard (obiter/argument); others not applicable.

holdings.text: Appropriate government has no power to cancel or supersede a reference made under s.10(1) ID Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Minerva Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt can appoint new tribunal after old expires; no question of cancelling s.10(1) reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Observation on cancellation was appellant's argument, not court's holding; no decision on power.

precedents_cited.case_name: Textile Workers Union, Amritsar v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Held implied power via s.21; erroneous as ignores Act scheme.

precedents_cited.case_name: Iyyappen Mills Pvt. Ltd. v. State of Travancore-Cochin
precedents_cited.relevance: First tribunal ceased; like Minerva Mills.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harendranath Bose v. Second Industrial Tribunal
South India Estate Labour Relations Organisation v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Amendment/new matters ok as independent reference; not cancellation.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme for conciliation then adjudication; once referred under s.10(1), tribunal jurisdiction exclusive; no cancellation power.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Rule of construction for power to rescind notifications; not applicable to s.10(1) ID Act due to repugnant scheme.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Employment (Standing Orders) Act, 1946
statutes_cited.relevance: Certified standing orders settled by agreement.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court confirmed Patna High Court's finding that the notification issued by Bihar government cancelling the first two notifications is invalid and ultra vires; appeals dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Upholds HC's certiorari quashing Sep 17, 1955 notification and mandamus to tribunal.

key_quotes.text: "If the appellant has no authority to cancel or revoke a notification issued under s.10(1), the bona fides of the appellant can hardly validate the impugned cancellation."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The scheme of the relevant provisions would prima facie seem to be inconsistent with any power in the appropriate government to cancel the reference made under s.10(1)."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We have no hesitation in holding that the rule of construction enunciated by s.21 of the General Clauses Act in so far as it refers to the power of rescinding or cancelling the original order cannot be invoked in respect of the provisions of s.10(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
